title: Filing for my individual bankruptcy, but will my joint accounts with husband be discharged as well?
question: I filed for bankruptcy over 10 years ago. I have a judgement against me for a credit card bill and would like to take care of it by filing for bankruptcy again. I am a stay-at-home mom with no income. Other than the judgement ($12K), the debt I have is credit cards $4K, and a student loan ($12K).
question_tags: Divorce,Divorce and credit cards,Divorce and joint accounts,Dividing debts in a divorce,Credit card debt and divorce,Divorce and student loans,Community property in divorce,Divorce and bankruptcy,Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy means test,Joint accounts during bankruptcy,Debt,Nondischargeable debt and student loans,Bankruptcy and debt
answers: Attys Firth and Espada have accurately answered your questions. That said, from other facts you disclose, it appears you may be "judgment proof", meaning you have no separate non-exempt assets from which a creditor could collect. It is still advisable for you to meet with an experienced BK lawyer. Some of us offer a free consultation by phone or in person. Take us up on it before making a final decision.

When a married person files for bankruptcy, but the spouse does not, the following debts must be included in the bankruptcy: (1) debts that are in the name of the person filing the case, and (2) debts that are owed by both spouses. If the credit card was issued to both you and your husband (and both names appear on the bills) then the debt is reported in the bankruptcy, and will be discharged. The non-filing spouse's separate debts are not included and they are not discharged.

Your husband will be affected because he will have to provide his income information, including 6 months' worth of paycheck stubs, or other records if he's self employed. He will have to provide your attorney with copies of bank statements and tax returns (if he files them separately). He will have to participate in providing estimates of all community property assets. However, his credit will not be affected by your bankruptcy case. Whether he may be affected in other ways depends on what property you two own together, and how much of that property is exempt.

If you are married and filing by yourself you must nevertheless include your husband's income for calculation of the means test and his assets must be included in determining if you are over the exemption limits. You will be discharged on your debts and your liability on the joint credit card. However, your husband will still owe the full amount on the joint credit cards. (It is called joint and several liability.) Student loans are not dischargeable except in very narrow circumstances. see an experienced bankruptcy attorney for details.

If you are filing a chapter 7, then your debt alone will be discharged, the creditors have the right to go after your husband. If you are filing a chapter 13 there is a co debtor stay during the bankruptcy.
If the home and car were purchased during your marriage then they are community property, no matter how titled, and you must list in your bankruptcy. If there is to much equity in your properties then the Trustee may take and sell for the benefit of unsecured creditors.
You really should speak with a knowledgeable bankruptcy attorney soon and before you make any decisions.
